key_points: Taliban fighters overran three major cities in the north of Afghanistan on Sunday, marking significant territorial gains.
The cities included Kunduz, and the capitals of Sar-e Pol and Takhar provinces.
This rapid advancement signifies a sharp escalation in Taliban gains across Afghanistan following the withdrawal of U.S. forces.
In Takhar and Sar-e Pol, officials and security forces fled prior to the Taliban attacks.
Taliban fighters burst into Kunduz city's prison, releasing inmates including Taliban fighters to reinforce their attacks.
Afghan security forces are scrambling to secure prisons as militants target these for inmate releases.
Intense airstrikes were launched around Kunduz, but Afghan forces reportedly lack morale and a clear plan to retake the city.
Zabiullah Mujahid, a Taliban spokesman, claimed full control of key government buildings in the seized cities and urged Afghan forces to surrender.
The conflict escalation raises concerns over rising civilian casualties as the fighting moves into urban areas.
Despite the nearing end of U.S. military withdrawal, U.S. Central Command has not committed to ending airstrikes in support of Afghan forces.
spokespersons: Amr al-Din Wali (Provincial council member, Kunduz)
Abdul Malik Azimi (Deputy governor, Sar-e Pol province)
Deborah Lyons (U.N. special representative for Afghanistan)
